turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It gets a little chilly here at night sometimes. Especially if you're over near the bay.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Or would you rather I changed the subject?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How do you like our little hamlet?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I despise it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I don't suppose it offers much to the casual visitor. Unless you're thrilled by a collection of shacks on a hillside. It takes a while to get used to.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Where are you from originally, Annie?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: San Francisco.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How'd you happen to come here?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, someone invited me up for the weekend a long time ago.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I guess you knew that, anyway.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I suspected as much.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You needn't worry. It's over and done with. A long time ago.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Annie -- there's nothing between Mitch and me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Isn't there?  Maybe there isn't. Maybe there's never anything between Mitch and any girl.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I think I'll have some of that, too.  I was seeing quite a lot of him in San Francisco, you know.  And then, one weekend, he asked me up to meet Lydia.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: When was this?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Four years ago. Of course, that was shortly after his father died.  Things may be different now.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Different?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: With Lydia.  Did she seem a trifle distant?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: A trifle.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then maybe it isn't different at all. You know, her attitude nearly drove me crazy. I simply couldn't understand it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: When I got back to San Francisco I spent days trying to figure out just what I'd done to displease her.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And what had you done?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Nothing! I simply existed. So what was the answer? A jealous woman, right? A clinging possessive mother.  Wrong. With all due respect to Oedipus, I don't think that was the case at all.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Then what was it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Lydia liked me, you see. That was the strange part of it. In fact, now that I'm no longer a threat, we're very good friends.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Then why did she object to you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Because she was afraid.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Afraid you'd take Mitch?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Afraid I'd give Mitch.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Afraid of any woman who'd give Mitch the only thing Lydia can give him -- love.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Annie, that adds up to a jealous, possessive woman.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I don't think so. She's not afraid of losing her son, you see.  She's only afraid of being abandoned.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Someone ought to tell her she'd be gaining a daughter.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She already has a daughter.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What about Mitch? Didn't he have anything to say about this?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I can understand his position. He went through a lot with Lydia after his father died. He didn't want to risk going through it all over again.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: So it ended. Not immediately, of course. I went back to San Francisco, and I still saw Mitch every now and then... but we both knew it was finished.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Then what are you doing here in Bodega Bay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You get straight to the point, don't you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm sorry. Forgive me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, that's all right, I don't mind. I came up here for two reasons. To begin with, I was bored with my job in San Francisco. I was teaching at a private school there... well, you know, you probably went to one yourself.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then you know. Little girls in brown beanies. Deadly. Here I have a life. I'll go into that classroom on Monday morning, and I'll look out at twenty- five upturned little faces, and each of them will be saying, 'Yes, please give me what you have.'  And I'll give them what I have. I haven't got very much, but I'll give them every ounce of it. To me, that's very important. It makes me want to stay alive for a long long time.  That's the first reason.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And the second?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I wanted to be near Mitch.  It was over, and I knew it, but I wanted to be near him, anyway.  You see, I still like him a hell of a lot. That's rare, I think. I don't want to lose his friendship... ever.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: He wants me to go to Cathy's party tomorrow afternoon.  I said I would.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll be going, too, to help out. It should be fun, Melanie.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It seems so pointless.  I think I'll go to sleep. This has been a busy day.  My luggage.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Do you think I should go?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's up to you.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It's really up to Lydia, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Never mind Lydia. Do you want to go?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then go.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is anyone there?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Look.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Ohhh. Oh, the poor thing. He probably lost his way in the dark.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: He got a call from Dan Fawcett a little while ago. His chickens won't eat, either.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: It's what you said, Mom. Mr. Brinkmeyer's feed is no good.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: No, Cathy. He sold Mr. Fawcett a different brand.  You don't think they're getting sick, do you, Mitch?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch knows lots of people in San Francisco. Of course, they're mostly hoods.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Cathy!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Well, Mom, he's the first to admit it.  He spends half his day in the detention cells at the Hall of Justice.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: In a democracy, Cathy, everyone is entitled to a fair trial. Your brother's practice...

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mom, please, I know all the democracy jazz. They're still hoods.  He's got a client now who shot his wife in the head six times. Six times, can you imagine it?  I mean, even twice would be overdoing it, don't you think?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Just listen to them!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: If your father were here...

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch, can I bring the lovebirds in here?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mom, they're in a cage!

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: They're birds!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: They haven't harmed anyone.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Take them.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Miss Daniels?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: They're beautiful! They're just what I wanted! Is there a man and a woman? I can't tell which is which.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, I suppose...

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: I still don't understand how you knew I wanted lovebirds.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Your brother told me.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Is smoking fun?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh, I suppose so.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Could I have a puff?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't think your mother would like that.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Just a little one.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Why, it's just like air, isn't it?  When I grow up, I'm gonna smoke like a chimney! I'll be eleven tomorrow, you know.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Are you coming to my party?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't think so.  I have to get back to San Francisco.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Don't you like us?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Darling, of course I do!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Don't you like Bodega Bay?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't know yet.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch likes it very much. He comes up every weekend, you know, even though he has his own apartment in the city. He says San Francisco is just an ant hill at the foot of a bridge.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I guess it does get a little hectic at times.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: If you do decide to come, don't say I told you about it. It's supposed to be a surprise party.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Why didn't Annie stay for dinner?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: She said something about having to get home to take a call from her mother back East.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Oh. Where d'you want the coffee?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Take it into the living room, would you, hon?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: What's the matter with them?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: We've got an extra room upstairs and everything.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That road can be a bad one at night, Melanie.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yeah, but she'll be hitting all that traffic going back to San Francisco.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Did you put the cover on that cage, Mom?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch? Why are they doing this?  The birds.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know, honey.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Why are they trying to kill people?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I wish I could say. But if I could answer that, I could also tell you why people are trying to kill people.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Cathy! Get a blanket and some bandages!

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Is she all right?

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch, let's turn back.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Shhh. Shhhhh.

turns.speaker: CATHY
turns.text: Mitch?  Do... do you think they'll be all right? In the trunk? Can they breath?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think they'll be all right, honey.

turns.speaker: HARRY'S VOICE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The little Brenner girl.

turns.speaker: HARRY'S VOICE
turns.text: Lois!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: It's Alice, ain't it?

turns.speaker: HARRY'S VOICE
turns.text: No, it's Lois!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: It's Alice.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I wonder if you could help me.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Try my best.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm looking for a man named Mitchell Brenner.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Do you know him?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Where does he live?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Right here. Bodega Bay.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, but where?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Right across the bay there.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: See where I'm pointing?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: See them two big trees across there?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: And the white house?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That's where the Brenners live.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The Brenners? Mr. and Mrs. Brenner?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Nope, just Lydia and the two kids.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The two kids?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yep. Mitch and the little girl.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I see. How do I get down there?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Follow the road straight through town 'til it curves off on the left. That'll take you right around the bay to their front door.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The front door.  Isn't there a back road I can take?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Nope. That's the road. Straight through town, stay on your left, right around the bay to the front door.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You see, I wanted to surprise them.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mmmm.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I didn't want to come right down the road, where they could see me.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mmmm.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It's a surprise, you see.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mmmmmm.  'Course, you could get yourself a boat, cut right across the bay with it. The Brenners got a little dock there you could tie up at. If that's what you wanted to do.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Where would I get a boat?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Down at the dock by the Tides Restaurant. Ever handled an outboard boat?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: D'you want me to order one for you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: What name?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Daniels.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I wonder if you could tell me...

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yep?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: The little girl's name.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The little Brenner girl?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Alice, I think.  Harry, what's the little Brenner girl's name?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Well, I ain't positive, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I need her exact name, you see.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: That case, I tell you what you do. You go straight through town 'til you see a little hotel on your left there. Not the motel, that's the other end of town. This is the hotel. Now you take a right turn there, you got that?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Near the top of the hill, you'll see the school and right behind it, the church. You head for the school. Now just past the school, you'll see a little house with a red mail box. That's where Annie Hayworth lives, she's the school teacher. You ask her about the little Brenner girl.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Yep.  Could save yourself a lot of trouble. Her name's Alice for sure.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Can I have the boat in about twenty minutes?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How much for the phone calls?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: It's nothing.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: I don't see what difference it makes, Mrs. Bundy, crows or blackbirds. If they attacked the school, that's pretty serious.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: I hardly think either species would have the intelligence to launch a massed attack. Their brain pans aren't large enough for such...

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: Mrs. Bundy, you don't seem to understand. This young lady says there was an attack on the school.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Impossible.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: I didn't even know there were many crows in Bodega Bay this time of year.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: The crow is a permanent resident throughout its range. In fact, during our Christmas Count, we recorded...

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: Why not, Mrs. Bundy?

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Because there are 8,650 species of birds in the world today, Mr. Carter. It's estimated that five billion, seven hundred and fifty million birds live in the United States alone. The five continents of the world...

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: What good'll that do? Smoke's as bad as birds.

turns.speaker: MRS. BUNDY
turns.text: Birds are not bad!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Deke, have you got a first aid kit back there?

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Young woman cut herself.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: Shall I call the doctor?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't think it's that serious. You want to sit up here?

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: You cut yourself outside, Miss?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Stop worrying, Deke. She was in a boat.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: I had a man trip and fall in the parking lot once, sued me before I could bat an eyelash.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't think Miss Daniels is going to sue anybody.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: Well, you're the lawyer.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: We don't have any fog this time of year, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We'll make our own fog.

turns.speaker: DEKE
turns.text: Gulls!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: They're back!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Are you finished here, Sebastian?

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: Let me have some apple pie, Helen.  Who said anything about war? All I said was that some gulls...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: One apple pie! You want more coffee?

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: No. ...came down on one of my boats. They could have been after the fish, just as you said.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Here's your pie, Sebastian. You want it at the table?

turns.speaker: SHOLES
turns.text: No. Here's fine.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Where are the Bloody Marys, Deke?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I thought I saw your car. What are you doing in town?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I had to acknowledge a delivery.  Mother, I'd like you to meet...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Melanie Daniels. Melanie, my mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: How do you do, Miss Daniels?  Acknowledge a what?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: A delivery, Mother. Miss Daniels brought some birds from San Francisco.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Oh. I see.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: For Cathy. For her birthday. By the way, where is she?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Across at Brinkmeyer's.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Miss Daniels is staying for the weekend. In fact, I've already invited her to dinner tonight.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: You did say birds?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes, lovebirds. We couldn't let you...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Lovebirds, I see.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: ...get away without thanking you in some small way. After all, you haven't even met Cathy and you are staying for the weekend...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Seven o'clock, same as usual.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'll pick you up, Miss Daniels. Where are you staying?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with those chickens, Mitch. I'm going to call Fred Brinkmeyer right now.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know what good that'll do.  Chickens won't eat.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: He sold the feed to me, didn't he?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Caviat emptor, Mother. Let the buyer beware.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Whose side are you on?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm simply quoting the law.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Never mind the law. Cathy, you can start serving the soup.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: She's a charming girl, isn't she, Mitch?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes, very.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: And certainly pretty.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: How long have you known her?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I told you. We met yesterday.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: In a bird shop.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: She was selling birds.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No. I only led her into believing I believed she was... Mother, it's really very complicated.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: But she did buy the lovebirds and then brought them all the way...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mother, where did you go to law school?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Forgive me. I suppose I'm just naturally curious about a girl like that.  She's very rich, isn't she?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I suppose so. Her father owns a big newspaper in San Francisco.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: You'd think he could manage to keep her name out of print. She's always mentioned in the columns, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I know, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: She is the one who jumped into that fountain in Rome last summer, isn't she?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Perhaps I'm old-fashioned.  I know it was supposed to be very warm there, Mitch, but... well... actually... well, the newspaper said she was naked.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I know, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: It's none of my business, of course, but when you bring a girl like that to...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mother?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think I can handle Melanie Daniels by myself.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Well...  So long as you know what you want, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I know exactly what I want, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Well... well, is everyone all right?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think he got a little scratch, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Tell him about the party.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That's right. We had a party here this afternoon for Cathy. Her birthday.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Did you you get the windows in the attic, Mitch?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I got them all, Mother.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: When do you think they'll come?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: If there are... larger birds, Mitch... they'll get into the house.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That's a chance we have to take.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Maybe we ought to leave.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Not now.  Not while they're massing out there.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know when.  We'll see what...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Where will we go?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know yet.  I think we'll be safe here.  Let's bring that wood in.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: What happens when we run out of wood?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know. We'll break up the furni...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: You don't know, you don't know! When will you know? When we're all dead? Like Annie?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mother! I'm trying my best!  I'm... trying... my...

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mitch.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Mitch...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Shhh. Shhh.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mother, get a rope!

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Oh, my God, look at her!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Get a rope!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I can handle it.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I know you can.  But I'd like to.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I'm not very good at this, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You're doing fine.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I mean. I want to...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: They're gone. The same pattern.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: But they'll be back.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We won't be here.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Where can we go, Mitch? There's no place to go.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I want to try for San Francisco. There are buildings there. Steel and concrete!

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: We'd never make it. They're probably all over the road.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We have to try it.  We can't stay here.  Melanie needs help.  Mother, the house won't take another attack.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: If...  If... when we get to San Francisco...  If they're already there?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: They won't be.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: If they are?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We'll worry about that when we get there.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I'm frightened, terribly frightened. I... I don't know what's out there, Mitch.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What do we have to know, Mother? We're all together, we all love each other, we all need each other. What else is there? Mother, I want us to stay alive!

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I started to say... inside...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You don't have to.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Then you knew Mitch in San Francisco, is that right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, not exactly.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: If I go across to Santa Rosa I'll come onto the freeway much earlier.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Yeah, and the freeway's well-lighted, isn't it, Mitch?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, it's me, Mrs. Brenner. I thought you might like some tea.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Where's Mitch?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Al Malone wanted him out at the Fawcett farm.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Why? Didn't Al believe my story?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: He was calling from the farm, Mrs. Brenner.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Then he saw.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: He must have. He sent for the Santa Rosa police.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: What good will they do?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Do you think Cathy's all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Cathy. At the school.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, I'm sure she's fine.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Do I sound foolish to you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I keep seeing Dan Fawcett's face.  They have such big windows at the school.  All the windows were broken. In Dan's bedroom. All the windows.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Try not to think of that, Mrs. Brenner.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I wish I were a stronger person. There is a long awkward silence. She sips at her tea reflectively.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I lost my husband four years ago, you know.  It's odd how you depend on someone for strength, and then suddenly all the strength is gone, and you're alone.  I'd love to relax some time. I'd love to be able to sleep.  Do you think Cathy's all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Annie's there. She'll be all right.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I'm not this way, you know. Not usually. I don't fuss and fret over my children.  When Frank died...  You see, he knew the children, he really knew them. He had the knack of being able to enter into their world, of becoming a part of them. That's a rare talent.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I wish I could be that way.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I miss him.  You know, sometimes I wake up in the morning, and I think 'I have to make Frank's breakfast,' and I... I get up and there's a... a very good reason for getting out of bed until... until, of course, I remember.  I miss talking to him.  Cathy's a child, you know, and Mitch...  ...Mitch has his own life.  I'm glad he stayed here today. I feel safer with him here.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Would you like to rest now, Mrs. Brenner.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: No.  No... don't go yet.  I feel as if I... I don't understand you. And I want so much to understand.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why, Mrs. Brenner?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Because my son is...  My son seems to be fond of you.  And I...  I'm not quite sure how I feel about it. I really don't know if I... like you or not.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Is that so important, Mrs. Brenner? You liking me?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Yes, I think so. My son is important to me. I want to like any girl he chooses.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And if you don't?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Then I don't suppose it'll matter much to anyone but me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think it might also matter to Mitch.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Mitch has always done exactly what he wanted to do.  I'm not complaining. That's the mark of a man.  But...  You see, I... I wouldn't want to be... be left alone. I don't think I could bear being left alone.  I... forgive me. This business with the birds has me upset.  I... I don't know what I'd do if Mitch weren't here.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why don't you try to sleep now, Mrs. Brenner.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I wish I were stronger.  Do you think she's all right? Do you think she's safe at the school?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Would you like me to go for her?

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: I couldn't ask you to.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't mind, really.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Would you? I'd feel so much better.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'll just clear up here, and then dress.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That's the last of it.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Did you close the door?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And locked it.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Please don't mess me up with bandages, Mrs. Brenner.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Shhhh. Shhhh.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: That's a chimney swift, all right.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We know what it is, Al.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Well, these birds live in chimneys, you know.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Not by the thousands.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: No, I gotta admit this is peculiar.  Did you have a light burning or something.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes, but the curtains were drawn.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: 'Cause sometimes birds are attracted by light, you know.  Sure is a peculiar thing.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What are we going to do about it, Al?

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: I don't think I get you, Mitch. Do about what?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Well...  Well... these birds attacked us.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: What's more likely, they got in the room and was just panicked, that's all.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: All right, I'll grant you a bird'll panic in an enclosed room. But, they didn't just get in. They came in! Right down that chimney.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: My wife found a bird in the back seat of her car once.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Didn't know how he got in there. Had a broken leg, turned out. Just fluttering all around there.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: These birds were...

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: What I'm trying to say, Mitch, is these things happen sometimes, you know? Ain't much we can do about it.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Oh, yeah, yeah.  How old is she now?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Eleven. In the middle of the party, some gulls came down at the children. And Miss Daniels was attacked by a gull just yesterday after...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Does this room look silly?

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: No, you got quite a mess here, I'll admit that.  Maybe you oughta put some screening on top of your chimney  Seems a little pointless, though. Freak accident like this wouldn't happen again in a million years.  You want some help cleaning up?

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Well, if there's anything else I can do, Mitch...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Thanks, Al. We'll be all right.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Goodnight, Lydia.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: He was killed last night. By birds.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: Now hold it, Mitch. You don't know that for a fact.

turns.speaker: MALONE
turns.text: There's an ordinance against burning anything in this town, unless it's...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We'll use smoke pots. Like the Army uses.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Is that for Mitch Brenner?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: He's not home.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That's all right.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: He won't be back until Monday. I mean, if those birds are for him....

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Monday?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Yes. I don't think you should leave them in the hall, do you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, I...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, where did he go?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Bodega Bay. He goes up there every weekend.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Bodega Bay? Where's that?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Up on the coast. About sixty miles north of here.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Sixty...  Oh.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: About an hour and a half on the freeway. Or two if you take the coast highway.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I'd hold the birds for him, but I'm going away myself. Someone's got to feed them, I suppose.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes. Yes, someone's got to feed them.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: I'm awfully sorry.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I wonder if you could help me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I said I wonder if you could help me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, what was it you were looking for, sir?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Lovebirds.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Lovebirds, sir?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes. I understand there are different varieties, it that true?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well... yes, sir, there are.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: These are for my sister... her birthday you see. As she'll be eleven and... well, frankly, I wouldn't want a pair of birds that were too demonstrative.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I understand completely, sir.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: As the same time, I wouldn't want birds that were aloof, either.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, of course not.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you have a pair that are just friendly?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think so, sir.  Now then, let me see.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Aren't these lovebirds?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No, sir, those are... redbirds.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: The sign says strawberry finches.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, we call them that too.  Ahhh, here we are, Lovebirds...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Those are canaries, Miss.  Doesn't this make you feel awful?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Doesn't what make me...?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: All these innocent little creatures caged up like this?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well, we can't just let them fly around the shop, you know.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I suppose not. Is there an ornithological reason for keeping them in separate cages?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh, certainly. It's to protect the species.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I imagine that's very important. Especially during the moulting season.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, that's a particularly dangerous time.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Are they moulting now?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Some of them are.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: How can you tell?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Well... they get a sort of hangdog expression.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes, I see.  About those lovebirds, Miss...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Are you sure you wouldn't like to see a canary instead? We have some very nice canaries this week.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: All right.  She smiles back.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I was merely drawing a parallel, Miss Daniels.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: But how... how do you know my name?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: A little birdie told me.  Good day, Miss Daniels.  Madam.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Hey, wait a minute!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't know you.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Ahhh, but I know you.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: We met in court.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: We never met in court or anyplace else.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That's true. I'll rephrase it. I saw you in court.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you remember one of your practical jokes that resulted in the smashing of a plate glass window?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I didn't break that window!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No, but your little prank did. The judge should have put you behind bars!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What are you? A policeman?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I simply believe in the law, Miss Daniels, and I'm not too keen on practical jokers.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What do you call your lovebird story if not a practical...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Ahhh, but I really do want those birds.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: You knew I didn't work here. You deliberately...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Right. I recognized you when I came in. I thought you might like to know what it felt like to be on the other end of a gag. What do you think of that, Miss Daniels?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I think you're a louse.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I am.  Good day.  Madam.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: And I'm glad you didn't get your lovebirds!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'll find something else.  See you in court some day.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That was the damndest thing I ever saw.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What made it...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It deliberately came down at you -- you're bleeding...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Just some peroxide. I want to clean out the cut.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: So you're a lawyer.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: That's right. What are you doing in Bodega Bay?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Do you practice here?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: No, San Francisco. What are you...?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What kind of law?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Criminal.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Is that why you'd like to see everyone behind bars?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Not everyone, Miss Daniels.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Only violators and practical jokers.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Ouch!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm sorry.  What are you doing up here?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Didn't you see the lovebirds?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You came all the way up here to bring me those birds?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: To bring your sister those birds. You said it was her birthday. Besides, I was coming up anyway.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: To see a friend of mine.  Will you please be careful?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm sorry.  Who's your friend?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Annie. Annie Hayworth.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Well, well, small world. Annie Hayworth.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: How do you know Annie?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: We... we went to school together. College.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Did you! Imagine that! How long will you be staying?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Just a few... just a day or two... the weekend.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think we'll have to shave the hair. Deke, have you got a razor?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh, no you don't!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It's still bleeding a little. Here, let me put this on.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: So you came up to see Annie, huh?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't believe you.  I think you came up to see me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why would I want to see you, of all people?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I don't know. But it seems to me you must have gone to a lot of trouble to find out who I was, and where I lived and...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It was no trouble at all. I simply called my father's paper. Besides, I was coming up here anyway, I already told you...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You like me, huh?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I loathe you. You have no manners. And you're arrogant and conceited and... I wrote you a letter about it, in fact, but I tore it up.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What did it say?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: None of your business.  Am I still bleeding?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Can't see a thing.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I can't say I like your seagulls much, either. I come all the way up here to...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: But you were coming up anyway, remember?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I was! And all I get for my pains is a... a... a hole in the head!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Right next to the one you already had.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Look, Mr. Brenner...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: After all, you did go to the trouble of bringing up those birds.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm sorry. I couldn't possibly...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, but...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You are, aren't you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Certainly, but...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Then it's settled. What time is dinner, Mother?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: With... with Annie, of course.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Of course, how stupid of me. A quarter to seven, will that be all right?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Annie... Annie may have made other plans. I'll have to see. Besides, I can find my own way.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You're sure now? You won't hire a boat or anything?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Seven o'clock then.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Hi. Annie had no plans, huh? I'm glad you came. Are you hungry?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Famished.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Dinner's just about ready.  We were out back looking at the chickens. Something seems to be wrong with them.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why did he shoot her?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: He was watching a ball game on television.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: His wife changed the channel.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You'll be able to find your way back, won't you?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Will I be seeing you again?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: San Francisco's a long way from here.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'm in San Francisco five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you.  Maybe we could go swimming or something. Mother tells me you like to swim.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: How does Mother know what I like to do?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I guess she and I read the same gossip columns.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Oh. That. Rome.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get along very...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: In case you're interested, I was pushed into that fountain.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Without any clothes on?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: With all my clothes on!  The newspaper that ran the story happens to be a rival of my father's paper.  Anything they said...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but the truth of that particular...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, but...

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: ...who didn't much care for propriety or convention or...

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: ...the opinions of others, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Sure. Do you really know Annie Hayworth?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No.  At least, I didn't until I came up here.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: So you didn't go to school together.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: And you didn't come up here to see her.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: You were lying.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes, I was lying.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Did you really write a letter to me? Or was that a lie, too?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I wrote the letter.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What did it say?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think you need those lovebirds, after all. They may help your personality." That's what it said.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: But you tore it up.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Because it seemed stupid and foolish.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I told you what happened in Rome!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: Do you expect me to believe...?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I don't give a damn what you believe!

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I'd still like to see you.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: I think it could be fun.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: That might have been good enough in Rome last summer. But it's not good enough now.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: It is for me.

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: But not for me.

turns.speaker: MITCH
turns.text: What do you want ?

turns.speaker: MELANIE
turns.text: I thought you knew! I want to go through life laughing and beautiful and jumping into fountains naked! Good night!
